run on repeat:

1. Daily Check-In (5 minutes)

â†³ Skip the small talk, this is your rhythm reset.
â†³ Run it even if a few folks miss it.

2. Weekly Tactical (45â€“90 minutes)
â†³ Turn updates into traction.
â†³ Name whatâ€™s stuck. Celebrate what moved.
â†³ Start with metrics. Then solve, donâ€™t spiral.

3. Monthly Strategic (2â€“4 hours)
â†³ Zoom out. Think long-term.
â†³ Ask better questions. Make smarter bets.

4. Quarterly Offsite (1â€“2 days)
â†³ New space. Bigger vision.
â†³ Get off Zoom. Clear the whiteboard.
â†³ Focus on team health and bold direction.

ğŸ‰ 30 Years of Deutsche Telekom! ğŸ‰

500 guests, classical and modern music, sports, politics, two grand pianos (in Bonn and Hamburg) coming together for a piece of music, and an elephant. Yesterday, we kicked off the celebrations for the 30th anniversary of Telekom with a festive event. We celebrated ourselves, and we were also celebrated a little: 200,000 Telekom employees worldwide.

Who would have thought that the authority called Telekom would once become a modern company? Growing from 37 million to over 300 million customers worldwide? Increasing revenue from 34 billion to 116 billion euros? And rising from number six to the most valuable telecom company in Europe?

Our journey has been one of transformation and design. It has been about decision-making and action. But above all, it has been about people. Like Ron Sommer, who visionary opened up new markets. Or Kai-Uwe Ricke, who took Telekom out of debt and made new investments possible. Or my friend RenÃ© Obermann, who, like no one else, put our customers at the center of our operations. Most importantly, it has been the many Telekom employees who are with us today or who once were. Those who never gave up. Those who continually reinvented themselves and our company, even in the face of headwinds. Change has also left wounds. That is part of our history.

Birthdays certainly evoke nostalgia and reflection. But not reflection that keeps us stagnant. Instead, reflection that serves as motivation. We, too, must reinvent Telekom every day. AI represents a significant revolution. If we use it wisely, we will become even more efficient, customer-oriented, and faster. Hopefully: unbeatable.

My highlight yesterday was the unveiling of the "Gran elephant dret" by Miquel BarcelÃ³. It symbolically represents what Telekom stands for: It is no longer "gray and sluggish." Instead, it is colorful and agile, curious and playful. The elephant that now stands in front of the Telekom headquarters should remind us to "Think again!" It embodies the power of change and the courage to continually reinvent the future. Those who understand the art of making the impossible possible can also achieve remarkable feats.

Thank you to our guests, the Beethoven Orchestra with Dirk Kaftan, Walter Smerling from the Kunst und Kultur Foundation, Mayor Katja DÃ¶rner, Prime Minister (NRW) Hendrik WÃ¼st, Digital Minister Karsten Wildberger, Minister Nathanael Liminski, Philipp Schindera , and everyone who contributed to the success of our festive event.

The "T" in the Deutsche Telekom logo will also continue to stand for transformation and technology, but also for trust and teamwork. And recently also for TÃ¶rrÃ¶Ã¶Ã¶!

#DeutscheTelekom #30Years #Innovation #Transformation #ConnectingYourWorld

McDonald's trusted an AI chatbot with 64 million job applications. Hackers needed just six keystrokes to access them all.

â¡ï¸ I've seen plenty of security failures, but this one takes the McFlurry. Security researchers just exposed how McDonald's AI hiring platform left millions of job seekers' data vulnerableâ€”protected by a password that would embarrass a middle schooler: '123456'.

â¡ï¸ The platform, built by Paradox.ai, features an AI chatbot named Olivia that screens applicants through McHire.com. Researchers Ian Carroll and Sam Curry discovered they could access 64 million application records simply by guessing administrator credentials. 

â¡ï¸ No multifactor authentication. No security checks. Just instant access to names, emails, phone numbersâ€”everything applicants shared while desperately trying to explain their job experience to a confused chatbot.

â¡ï¸ The breach reveals a darker pattern in our rush to automate everything. We're handing over sensitive human moments, like job applications, to AI systems secured with less care than your Netflix account.This incident crystallizes three uncomfortable truths about our AI-powered future:

ğŸ‘‰ Companies deploy AI for efficiency but forget basic security fundamentals
ğŸ‘‰ The most vulnerable data often belongs to those seeking entry-level work
ğŸ‘‰ Human oversight remains critical when machines handle human dignity

â“ When we delegate human processes to machines, we inherit new responsibilities, not shed them.  As we accelerate toward AI-mediated everything, here's my question: Should companies be required to match their security investment to their automation ambitions?

Read the full article on WIRED: https://lnkd.in/g8sB7xnT

#Cybersecurity #AIEthics #DataBreach #FutureOfWork #Privacy #Automation

lemlist recently crossed $34,000,000 ARR.

Here's every tool they use to run their SaaS:

Their CEO, Charles Tenot, was kind enough to share their entire tech stack â†“


1ï¸âƒ£ Content 

Their team has a combined 300,000+ LinkedIn follower count.

This includes their Founder Guillaume's account (23,000+ followers), their CEO Charles (29,000+) and other teammates such as KÃ©vin (78,000+), Lucas (57,000+), Tal (34,000+), Erwan (32,000+) & others.

They use:

- Taplio, their own platform, for content planning, ideation, and analytics.
- Figma to design infographics & carousels.

They drive 200,000+ visitors to their site every month. For SEO, they use:

- Google Search Console to monitor their website's organic performance.
- Ahrefs & Semrush to research keywords & monitor rankings.
- Storyblok as their content management system (CMS).


2ï¸âƒ£ Outbound

Since their main product, lemlist, is an all-in-one prospecting platform, it's also the tool they use most for outbound.

On top of that, they source data from several platforms:

- B2B databases: People Data Labs, Apollo, lemlist.
- Technology data: BuiltWith
- Funding data: Crunchbase

For Data enrichment, their platform includes a waterfall with the best email finders on the market (incl. Prospeo.io).

They also use a few intent signal platforms:

- LoneScale to monitor new job openings, job changes & new hires.
- Snitcher for website visitor identification.
- G2 for SaaS buyers' intent.

For 'complex' data use-cases (niche data sourcing, deep ai agentic research), they use Clay.

For deliverability, they use their email warmup platform, lemwarm.

They leverage AI models like OpenAI, Claude, Mistral AI, and use Dust, an AI agent builder.


3ï¸âƒ£ Product

They use a few software for production data, including:

- BigQuery as their data warehouse.
- Google Cloud to deploy applications.
- Holistics Data as a business intelligence platform for analytics.
- RudderStack & dbt Labs as customer data platform for data transformation.

For prototyping, they use:

- Vercel V0 for code generation & user interface.
- Replit to develop & deploy software.


4ï¸âƒ£ Funnel

They convert around ~7-8% of their 200K+ monthly visits into signups. This amounts to 15,000+ new signups every month.

To track product/website metrics, they use:
- Mixpanel
- Google Analytics

To extract, transform, load & synchronise data across every department, they useÂ Hightouch, which is what's called a 'reverse ETL platform'.

Then, their marketing stack includes:
- Customer.io (for email marketing)
- Default (for lead routing)
- Webflow (website)


5ï¸âƒ£ Sales

Their sales team, led by Yann Guilleux, has been on fire lately.

We're talking $685K in ARR closed last month.

Their sales stack includes:
- Hyperline for contracts, custom quotes, invoicing.
- Spoke for meetings recordings/transcripts.
- lemcal to schedule meetings.
- HubSpot as their CRM.

I'm running out of space given the number of tools, haha!

What if the real disruption in manufacturing isnâ€™t coming from AI, cloud, or automation... but from the uncomfortable realization that weâ€™ve been investing in all the wrong things?

According to Deloitteâ€™s 2025 Smart Manufacturing Survey, manufacturers are pouring billions into tech. ğŸ•ğŸ–% are allocating over ğŸğŸ% of their improvement budgets to smart manufacturing. ğŸ’ğŸ”% are prioritizing process automation.

Not in our culture. 
Not in our org structures. 
Not in how we prepare our people.

The data exposes the gap. Human capital is the least mature capability in the smart manufacturing stack. Only ğŸ’ğŸ–% of companies have a training and adoption standard. Yet itâ€™s the number one area they say they want to improve. And while ğŸ–ğŸ“% believe smart manufacturing will attract new talent, more than a third say their biggest human capital concern is simply adapting workers to the factory of the future.

We like the sound of digital transformation as long as it doesn't slow us down. We like the optics of AI as long as we don't have to redesign how we work. We like talking about the workforce of the future as long as we donâ€™t have to train the one we already have.

So yes, investment is rising. But if we donâ€™t confront the outdated systems and assumptions holding us back, all weâ€™re doing is layering expensive tech on fragile foundations.

The biggest barrier to smart manufacturing isnâ€™t budget, technology, or even talent.

Itâ€™s us.

Here are 8 practical phrases that helped me set boundaries and reclaim my confidence:

1ï¸âƒ£ When they try to guilt you: 
"I understand how you feel, but Iâ€™m confident in my decision."

2ï¸âƒ£ When they dismiss your feelings: 
"My feelings are valid, and Iâ€™d appreciate it if you respected them."

3ï¸âƒ£ When they constantly criticize you: 
"I welcome constructive feedback, but this doesnâ€™t feel helpful."

4ï¸âƒ£ When they play the victim: 
"I hear what youâ€™re going through, but I canâ€™t take responsibility for this."

5ï¸âƒ£ When they spread negativity: 
"Letâ€™s focus on what we can control and improve."

6ï¸âƒ£ When they gaslight you: 
"I know my experience, and this is how I see it."

7ï¸âƒ£ When they try to control the situation: 
"I understand your perspective, but I need to make my own decisions."

8ï¸âƒ£ When they interrupt you: 
"Iâ€™d appreciate it if I could finish speaking before you share your thoughts."

Youâ€™re not responsible for fixing toxic people.

But you are responsible for protecting 
your energy, your values, and your peace.

Speak up. 
Stand firm.

Every boundary you set teaches others how to treat you.

âœ”ï¸Here is detailed information about the Arduino Uno:

Overview:

The Arduino Uno is a microcontroller board based on the ATmega328P. It is one of the most popular boards in the Arduino family. ideal for beginners and hobbyists.

Pin Diagram Explanation:

1. Digital Pins (0-13): For input/output operations (like reading switches. controlling LEDs).

2. Analog Pins (A0-A5): Read analog sensors like temperature or light.

3. PWM Pins (3.5.6. 9. 10. 11): Provide Pulse Width Modulation for dimming LEDs or controlling motors.

4. TX (1) and RX (0): Used for serial communication.

5. Power Pins:

Vin: Input voltage.

5V/3.3V: Output regulated voltage.

GND: Ground.

AREF: Analog Reference voltage.

Communication Options:

Serial (UART)

I2C (A4-SDA. A5 SCL)

SPI (Pins 10 SS. 11 MOSI. 12 - MISO. 13-SCK)

GND: Ground.

AREF: Analog Reference voltage.

Programming the Board:

Use Arduino IDE (available for Windows. macOS. Linux).

Select Board: Arduino Uno and correct COM port.

Upload code via USB using standard A-B USB cable.

 Common Uses:

LED & buzzer control

Sensor interfacing

Robotics

Home automation

IoT (with WiFi modules)

Educational electronics

Advantages:

Easy to use and program

Extensive documentation and community support

Open-source hardware

Compatible with many shields

Leaderâ€™s perspectives I "AI at Work: Transforming with Deloitte, SAP and AWS"

@Netra Saxena, Associate Director, Deloitte India, spoke passionately about how AI can be applied to real business processes, not just as a concept but as a value-driving engine across industries. She shared how these AI solutions are delivered using SAP BTP and how they can be seamlessly lifted and shifted to other hyperscalers to align with clientsâ€™ infrastructure preferences. A highlight of the session was the introduction of a new platform offering, AgentX, which enables end-to-end business process orchestration powered by Agentic AI. With AgentX, organisations can move beyond traditional automation and empower digital agents to reason, act and collaborate across systems.

Real use cases showcased:
â€¢ Smart reporting: Build real-time, on-demand reports with embedded insights, removing the dependency on static dashboards or BI teams.
â€¢ Intelligent invoicing: Automate the extraction of invoice details from documents and trigger direct posting into ERP systems with validation checks, reducing cycle time and manual effort.
â€¢ Concept to case: Turn ideas into structured business cases using GenAI, instantly capturing problem statements, benefits, dependencies and ROI narratives.

Together, these solutions show how AI is already delivering measurable results, helping organisations drive efficiency, agility and long-term strategic impact.

The goal was always clear: identify and integrate strong, complementary companies that share our values and ambition.

This acquisition reinforces our commitment to expanding our capabilities and market reach. There are considerable opportunities in the Southeast Europe market, and we will continue to evaluate and identify target companies for our further market expansion, the ones that align with our company culture, products, and services, ensuring they are fit for our strategic development in the future.

Big news to share: Praxis Labs has been acquired by Torch!

When Elise Smith and I first met 7 years ago, we connected on the basis that workplaces are not set up for all of us to succeed. And that we needed more human-centered and inclusive leaders to engage diverse perspectives, build resilient teams, and create better products and services for us all. 

I am forever grateful for that first coffee date, and the email that Elise sent the entire eng listserve (I see you GSB students emailing Stanford eng ğŸ‘€) that sparked my interest. It was the start of our journey with Praxis Labs. While there have been many twists and turns â€“ COVID, a bank run, politicization of DEI â€“ the decision to believe in ourselves, in the potential for change, and in a better future is one of the best decisions Iâ€™ve made. 

Joining forces with Torch marks an exciting new chapter and opportunity. Praxis is built on the belief that real-world practice, personalized coaching, and concrete skills measurement can reshape how people learn, grow, and perform. AI skills will be crucial for years to come. 

Knowing how to use ChatGPT isnâ€™t enough. 

Learn these AI skills to future-proof your career: 

(remember to ğŸ”– save for later) 

1. Prompt Engineering:
Write better instructions to help AI tools give you exactly what you need.

2. AI Workflow Automation:
Link different apps together to help you complete tasks automatically.

3. AI Agents:
Use AI systems that act like teammates to handle tasks together.

4. Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG):
Link AI chatbots to your private files for more accurate answers.

5. Multimodal AI:
Use AI that understands pictures, sounds, and text all at once.

6. Fine-Tuning and AI Assistants:
Build custom AI models or assistants tailored to your needs.

7. Voice AI and Avatars:
Make realistic AI voices and avatars for videos and presentations.

8. AI Tool Stacking:
Use tools like Notion, Zapier, and ChatGPT together to work faster.

9. AI Video Content Generation:
Turn your ideas or blog posts into professional videos using AI.

10. SaaS Development:
Build small AI-powered apps using no-code tools.

11. LLM Management:
Keep track of how well your AI tools are working and what they cost.

12. Stay Updated:
Follow top AI news sites to stay ahead of trends and new tools.

AI wonâ€™t replace you.Â

Deploy AI agents like theyâ€™re part of your team. Follow AI Agent in Action for more ideas like this.

Everyone's building the same three AI products.

AI SDR. AI meeting notes. AI chatbot.

10,000 startups. 3 ideas. Zero taste.

I see pitch decks every week. "We're like Gong but with AI." "We're Salesforce with a chatbot." "We're the AI version of [insert any SaaS tool]."

Last week, a customer asked me for call recording features. I told him straight up:

"I am NOT a call recorder. You are offending me with these questions. I'm here to serve your customers."

He looked confused. Like I'd just told him I don't believe in gravity.

That's the problem. We're so obsessed with making AI do what humans used to do, we forgot to imagine what it could do that humans never could.

Take customer success. Everyone's racing to build AI that writes better follow-up emails. But what if the problem isn't the email quality? What if it's that we're sending emails at all?

What if instead of 10 touchpoints over 3 months, you could have one perfect interaction at exactly the right moment?

What if instead of quarterly business reviews, you had continuous intelligence flowing between you and your customer?

What if instead of "scaling" customer success, we reimagined it entirely?

This is what taste looks like in the AI era. Not copying what exists and adding a chatbot. But questioning every assumption about how business works.

The winners won't be the ones who build AI versions of old software. They'll be the ones who use AI to build things that were never possible before.

That's the difference between following and leading. Between copying and creating.

Between having taste and having none.

Stop building better note-takers. Start building better businesses.
